awd_titl_txt: Conference: Synthetic Biology: Engineering, Evolution and Design (SEED) Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2023 Synthetic Biology, Engineering, Evolution and Design (SEED) Conference will have an expanded range of topics and will emphasize burgeoning areas of synthetic biology such as synthetic applications for climate change and sustainability, and microbiome engineering for food and the environment.  The broader range of topics will allow the conference to host scientists and engineers with diverse backgrounds. The conference will also allow students and early career professionals to share their work and learn about new advances in a rapidly growing field. Additionally, the conference will promote the continuous growth of members of the synthetic biology community, encouraging discussions among normally separated scientists and engineers and encouraging collaborations, which are critical for the development of new synthetic technologies and applications for biotechnology, agriculture and medicine.

Over the past decade, the field of synthetic biology has rapidly developed from a research-based, theoretical discipline to one that is impacting society and will continue to grow in applications into the future. Since 2014, SEED has been the primary technical conference to gather people working in synthetic biology, including engineers, biologists, chemists, electrical engineers, computer scientists and more. The conference gathers an interdisciplinary audience to share technical presentations on cutting edge research and applications, network to develop relationships and connect people who may otherwise not have an opportunity to interact. Attendees include leaders in the field, established researchers, early career professionals and trainees who will lead the field in the coming decades. SEED’s goal is to share insights into next-generation development strategies in synthetic biology research and industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Conference: 2023 Synthetic Biology: Engineering, Evolution and Design Conference

Project Outcomes Report
Award 2322816

The 2023 Synthetic Biology: Engineering, Evolution and Design (SEED) Conference took place May 30 – June 2 at the Hilton Los Angeles/Universal City Hotel in Los Angeles, California. SEED continues to be the largest and highest quality technical event for synthetic biology, covering the field from its research foundations to commercial applications. Gathering 418 attendees SEED covered a wide array of topics within synthetic biology, including:

  • Synthetic neurobiology
  • Next-Gen Gene Circuit Regulation
  • Synthetic Cells and Cell Free Systems
  • Synthetic Biology for Climate and Environment Sustainability
  • Biomolecules: Computation, Design and Evolution
  • Microbiome Engineering for Health, Food and the Environment
  • Multicellular and Organ-Scale Engineering
  • The Future of Food and Natural Medicines
  • Biological Information Storage and Computing
  • Big-data and Synthetic Biology
  • Engineered Biomedicines
  • Engineered Living Materials

Over the course of the 4 day conference, world leading researchers presented on cutting-edge developments over the past year. Over 50 oral presentations and panels took place during the conference. Additionally, over 150 trainees and early career professionals presented their work during the poster sessions. Breaks, lunches, receptions and other networking sessions throughout the meeting provided opportunities for attendees to connect in a more informal setting, exchanging ideas for future collaborations and discussion career development opportunities, which help synthetic biology continue to advance.

Keynote and invited speakers represented a wide range of backgrounds and expertise areas, showing the various ways synthetic biology is impacting science and society. Speakers included:

  • Bryn Adams, Army Research Lab
  • Caroline Ajo-Franklin, Rice University
  • Lacra Bintu, Stanford University
  • Jennifer Brophy, Stanford University
  • Yvonne Chen, University of California, Los Angeles
  • Adam Cohen, Harvard University
  • Hana El-Samad, Altos Labs
  • Michael Elowitz, California Institute of Technology
  • Xiaojing Gao, Stanford University
  • Albert Keung, North Carolina State University
  • Mustafa Khammash, ETH Zurich
  • Chang Liu, University of California, Irvine
  • Kole Roybal, University of California, San Francisco
  • Paul Sheehan, ARPA-H
  • Kevin Solomon, University of Delaware
  • Kelly Stevens, University of Washington
  • Jerzy Szablowski, Rice University
  • Alice Ting, Stanford University
  • Ranjani Varadan, Shiru
  • Chao Zhong, Center for Materials Synthetic Biology

Funds from the NSF were used to provide registration and travel support for students, post-docs and early career faculty at U.S.-based universities. Over 40 people were able to attend the conference thanks to NSF funding. This support allowed trainees and early career faculty, who often face financial limitations in attending conferences, the ability to gain valuable knowledge, connection and development opportunities at SEED.

 


Last Modified: 06/04/2024
Modified by: Evan Flach
